answers.answer: Honestly I do not believe you do have a malpractice suit. What is ultimately wrong with baby is genetic and that is out of the doctor's control. That is just my personal opinion. Others may disagree.I'm very sorry. Miracles DO happen everyday and you never know. Your little girl could surprise everyone and live longer!

I am so sorry to hear this. I would consult with a lawyer. When did you have an ultrasound? i ask this because, they should have been able to notice something was wrong on the ultrasound. at least thats what i think.

I am sorry you are going through this, but I agree with Joy- I don't see any fault with the physician. Trisomy 13 is a genetic condition- your baby had this from the very day she was conceived. The doctor seemed to do all that was standard- u/s measurements with a follow-up when the baby measured small. She also sent you to be monitored as a precaution. Some physicians might not have even done that.Did you do the first trimester screening? Did it come up with you at an increased risk for downs? Even if it didn't, the doctor still wouldn't be at fault since these tests are not 100% accurate.I too would be beside myself if my little darling had such problems. My heart goes out to you. But you cannot blame anyone- yourself, the doctor, anyone... I hope you are receiving counceling to help cope with this,

No, there is no malpractice suite available here. Regardless of whether you went to term or not, your baby would still be born with these genetic issues. It was all in the genes and had nothing to do with delivering  you early. I am so sorry you are going through this and I wish you nothing but the best in the future.

I agree with the other ladies.The doctor was monitoring you appropriately and delivered her early since your BP was elevated and her HB was not responding normally - these are both very dangerous situations for both mother and baby and can be fatal if action is not taken.As others have mentioned Trisomy is a rare condition that results from an error with DNA distribution during the conception process - it is no ones fault, not yours and not the doctors.  Sometimes these things go undetected as tests are not perfect.Im sorry for what you are going through.  A friend of a friend of mine recently gave birth to a baby with Trisomy - they didnt know until baby was born either.  The baby died several hours after birth.......

No malpractice here. UNLESS you did the first trimester screening, and the doctor told you everything was fine when it wasn't (and there has to be evidence that the doc saw the bad results but told you they were ok).- bf is a lawyer and he was just in a huge lawsuit regarding a pill they prescribe to some pregnant women, so he got a lot of info about birth laws and such.
My heart goes out to you.  Hugz:)

I'm sorry your dealing with this. I highly doubt that you'd have cause for a malpractice suit because you were well monitored throughout your pregnancy.The first trimester screening doctor's do has false negatives and false positives all the time. It's really not that accurate. Your doctor had no real cause for doing invasive testing for chromosome problems because she probably didn't see anything on the U/S.The only thing I  can think of that should've been caught was the cleft lip. Ultrasounds only catch about %60 of physical chromosomal abnormalities. Spend your time with your little girl and cherish her.You should also have some testing to see if you or the baby's father carry any mosaic trisome 13 either. Because sometimes mosaic can result in a case so minor it causes no problems in the parent, however makes it a higher chance of having children with the trisome.

I recently knew a lady whoes baby was born with this. Like everyone has said it is a genetic problem and not a doctor problem. It sounds like the docotr watched your baby well and even had her tested for stress then took her right away from the problems. I know how hurt you must be I lost my last daughter a few hours after birth. All I can say is to not make any big decisions for a year and just cherish the time you will be given. You do not want to put negative energy in the doctor and just all positive energy to your baby. That is what you both deserve. Wrap yopurself up in her and every moment you have. I will be preying for you and your family
Just got my medical records back for my doctor and I had hypertenstion and pre-clamca. do they test for these?

You said in your original post you had high blood pressure. Pre-eclampsia isn't something they can give you a test for. It just happens to some women when they're pregnant. Kind of like gestational diabetes...it just happens.

I had preeclampsia as well. It often just suddenly appears and there is no known cause. You are lucky the dr caught it early on because it can be dangerous for the mother and the baby. It would not have changed a chromosomal abnormality. HOnestly, it's possible that the early delivery actually gave you more time with your precious angel.

As easy as it is to want to find someone to blame, this was in God's hands.  As the others have said this was genetic....your doctor did not cause your child to have these abnormalities.  She was literally MADE that way.  It's understandable that you are scared, hurt, angry, upset, etc but honestly trying to point fingers isn't going to help.  They say she has 6 months to live, I would spend your time focusing on your beautiful baby girl, loving her, spoiling her, getting to know her, cherishing her and making wonderful memories with her.  I would also pray...a  LOT...miracles DO happen.  Just remember that while we may not understand WHY, ALL things DO happen for a reason.My first son was stillborn.  I, too, wanted to find someone to blame.  I had my 37 week check up, everythign was fine...he was good size, his heart rate was great...my then 5 yo even got to hold the dopplar to hear his heartbeat.  The next morning I went into labor, by the time my labor had progressed and we got to the hospital, he was gone.  There was nothing that could be done.  After the delivery we discovered that he had the umbilical cord wrapped around his neck twice so tight that the cord was flat.  In the beginng I wanted so much to blame the hospital, the doctors...I wanted answers, I wanted to know HOW something like that could have happened, how they couldn't have known.  But I finally realized that ultimately there was NOTHING anyone could have done.  Short of being monitored by ultrasound 24 hours a day there was no way to have known.  Even then, it's a possibility that it could have been missed.I think you need to redirect your attention and energy to enjoying your daughter, focus on her and how special she is.  Take tons of pictures, smother her with kisses, buy her cute clothes, hold her and most of all....love her with eveyrthing you have.

question: Ok, I gave birth my little girl on October 6th 2009. She weighted 3lb. and 1oz. and she was 16 inches long. My due date was November 8th 2009. I gave birth to her at 34 weeks and 5 days. My entire pregnancy my doctor said that my baby was progressing as normal and until Sept. 29th she said that I was measuring small. She did a weight ultrasound (and yes I understand that they are not that accurate) and she said that I measured a week small, but it was nothing to worry about. Then I was scheuled to go back to see her October 8th, but I was having really bad pain in my bottom (on October 6th). She said that I was still measuring small and did another weight ultrasound and she said that my baby had lost 12 oz. in 8 days ( but she said she didn't think it was accurate) so she sent me to the hospital for a fetul stress test. They put the straps around my belly and took my blood pressure and it was high. I laid there for about 2 hours and she said that everything looked good. Then my doctor suggested that the nurse buzz my belly (to startle my baby) and her heartrate dropped instead of going up. So she did an emergency c-section. My little girl went into respiratory distress was rushed to UAB (a learning hospital, a GREAT one at that). There she was diagnosed with Trisomy 13 Mosaic. 70% of her cells carry the trimosy gene and 30% does not. She had several congenital anomalies such as complete cleft lip on the right and partial cleft lip on the left, palpable cleft platate, clitoral enlargement, low set ears, microcephaly, hypotelorism, Flat nasal bridge, her neck was short with excess skin, short cternum with small nipples, long fingers, cataracts, rocker-bottom feet, and was SGA. After the doctor took my planceta out she said that it was small. My question is do I have a malpractice suite againist her? They have given my baby 6 months to live. I AM A WRECK!
title: Malpractice, maybe?!?!?!
